item.title: Governments Move to Bolster Aid as Global Coronavirus Deaths Top 184,000
item.description: U.S. lawmakers were expected to approve $484 billion in fresh aid to small businesses and hospitals, while EU leaders were meeting to debate a recovery plan for countries hit hardest by the pandemic’s economic fallout.

item.title: Global Economy Hit by Record Collapse of Business Activity
item.description: Business activity in the U.S., Europe and Japan collapsed in April as governments tightened restrictions on movement and social interaction aimed at limiting the spread of the coronavirus, according to surveys of purchasing managers.

item.title: In a Global First, Syrians Face Trial for State Torture
item.description: The first trial on Syrian state torture began in Germany, in what lawyers and human-rights groups see as a test case for the role European courts can play in accountability for war crimes committed in the Syrian conflict.

item.title: Coronavirus Threatens Southern Europe's Vital Tourism Industry
item.description: Hotels, restaurants, souvenir shops, ferry services and myriad other tourism-linked businesses across southern Europe struggle to survive as summer approaches and the pandemic continues.

item.title: Merkel Warns German States to Go Slow as Economy Reopens
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Thursday urged the country’s 16 states not to be hasty in lifting economic restrictions following a slowdown in new coronavirus infections.

item.title: Coronavirus Spurs Race in Latin America to Make Cheaper Ventilators
item.description: With the coronavirus pandemic bearing down and ventilators in short supply, engineers, entrepreneurs and physicians are coming together with an audacious goal: building their own breathing machines from scratch in a matter of weeks.
